awd_titl_txt: Algorithms for Assessing and Improving Joint Inversion
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the structure of the earth's subsurface is essential to modern society.  For example, this knowledge aids in building safe structures, allows us to locate minerals, hydrocarbons, groundwater and contaminants; map tunnels, pipes and mines.  The structure of the earth's subsurface can be understood by its material properties such as rock, soil and water.  However, these properties cannot be measured directly in the subsurface.  Therefore, non-invasive geophysical measurements are used to observe them.   This involves measuring an energy response at the earth's surface, after electromagnetic waves or electric currents are injected into the subsurface.  The mathematical approach to inferring an image of the subsurface from these energy observations is called inversion.  The major challenge in recovering a subsurface image is that no one single image results from a given energy response.   Recently, scientists have addressed this issue by using multiple types of energy to recover an image, which is referred to as joint inversion.  In this project, the PIs use joint inversion to combine observations of energy transfer from a large range of frequencies. The PIs hypothesize that with information from a large frequency range, a unique image can be created that is an accurate representation of the subsurface.  This approach can be extended to other fields such as wireless communication and video processing.  Therefore, the PIs will also develop a software package that can be used to decide if particular data types are complimentary.

Simultaneous joint inversion involves optimizing a single objective function with information from multiple types of data.  The PIs will combine complex electrical resistivity (ER) and ground penetrating radar (GPR) measurements in the Earth's subsurface, and determine the effectiveness of using both types of data.  The approach determines if and how the physics describing different types of data collection techniques contribute to abolishing the other's null space.   More generally, the PIs will determine how different types of data can most effectively regularize each other.  This will be done by quantifying decay rates of singular values of integral solutions describing the fundamental physics for ER and GPR data.  This requires the development and implementation of a framework through which the singular values in a joint inversion can be computed in a continuous setting.  The relationship between decay rates and an effective joint inversion will be tested with ER and GPR field data from the Boise Hydrological Research Site. This project helps bridge the gap between forward and inverse modeling by novel implementations and analyses in each field.

por.por_cntn:
The focus of this work was to develop new high-resolution methods for  exploration geophysics using non-invasive electrical methods of data collection. In particular, we used  ground penetrating radar (GPR) and direct current electrical resistivity (ER) to image the shallow subsurface of the Earth.  These images help us understand material properties of the subsurface and shed light on subsurface energy resources such as oil, gas and geothermal. The images also help us monitor CO2 sequestration sites and understand ground-water flow. 

Attached are two figures illustrating the field data that was used in this project.  One figure contains results using ER to find the location of ground water and dry sand at a site near the Boise river in Idaho. The second figure contains results when GPR was used to locate graves of inmates buried in the cemetery at the former Idaho State Prison in Boise. For each of these distinct methods of data collection, the resulting images of the subsurface were found using a mathematical method called inversion. Inversion is the process of solving mathematical equations  in a "backward" manner.  The process of inversion is backward because we reconstruct a mathematical model using geophysical observations, while a forward technique would be to use the mathematical model to predict earth properties.

This project developed optimal numerical models that utilized the distinct non-invasive data types of GPR and ER simultaneously.  More generally, our novel non-linear joint inversion algorithm iteratively combines different data types that share a common parameter space.  Combining different data types reduces the chance of obtaining an image that is not unqiue, which is a common problem not only in geophysical but also medical imaging. Since there are multiple types of data the approach is called joint inversion and we implemented it with Maxwell's equations.  These equations describe the physics of electric currents such as GPR and ER, and provide a mathematical model of the material properties of the earth.

With our technique, we were able to produce higher quality images than can be generated from just GPR or ER.  In particular our scheme improves the accuracy, frequency content, and depth resolution of the permittivity and conductivity that describe subsurface properties. In addition, we used the adjoint method to efficiently form the model and produced an algorithm that is more computationally efficient than current approaches.  The computationally efficient technique allows us to describe earth properties at a finer scale which improves resolution and is key to understanding physical processes such as ground water flow in hydrology, distrubution of snow density or fracture distribution in ice in glaciogy, or buried structure geometry in archaeology.
